segments.text: This is an interview with area court director Frank Keenan by Lisa Walker on the 23rd of November, 1989, at the Hidalgo International Bridge concerning the war on drugs.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge, I'm asking you to donate this tape to me or to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection at the University Archives.
Is that OK with you?
Yes.
It's quite OK. Great.
First of all, I'd like to hear a little bit about yourself.
What's your personal background and education?
Well, I grew up in Detroit, Michigan.
I'm a graduate of Wayne State University.
I have a master's degree from Eastern Michigan University.
I've been in customs since 1965.
I was an inspector in Detroit.
In 1972, I went to headquarters and was there, except for a couple of overseas assignments.
I was there continuously until about 1985.
And I was an operations officer in Houston, Texas.
And I've been here for the last two years as a port director.
Wow.
You've worked all over the place.
Okay, let's get started.
First of all, I'd like to ask you, what was the Customs Service's role in the war on drugs through the different administrations, starting with Carter and ending with President?
Well, my involvement in the war on drugs really started in 1973.
That was when President Nixon began to take a look and saw that
United States was having a major drug problem and every president since then has tried to commit resources to some kind of war on drugs.
Do you want to know what our role is?
Yes sir.
Customs is only one of many agencies involved in this.
We see the war on drugs as a multi

agency multinational operation customs is trying to control have jurisdiction on the borders airports and seaports at the ports of entry themselves when one gets away from the ports of entry that it becomes under the jurisdiction of border patrol
the Drug Enforcement Administration, and other local and federal agencies.
They're only really a small part of the total .
And has that role changed through the administrations, or has it changed?
I haven't seen any change at all from one administration to the other.
There was a slight difference between the

Nixon and Carter administrations I think maybe enforcement was downplayed somewhat during the Carter administration and then picked up again quite dramatically at least the at least verbally under Reagan and then it's continued under Bush I haven't seen any difference at all between the Reagan administration and Bush administration except
that President Bush has done what other presidents have tried to do, and that is to appoint somebody to be in charge of the total operation, Mr. Bennett.
But we haven't actually seen any action from that office yet.
I think things are still in the planning stage.
They haven't actually implemented what he has planned.
Oh, you were reading my mind.
That was my next question.
It was about the drug czar and if that's cut down and the overlapping of duties between the agencies.
I haven't seen any difference.
We're still turf conscious, unfortunately.
But it hasn't changed.
I worked between 1973 and about 1985
I worked overseas a good part of my time with other agencies, DEA.
A lot of the agents, DEA agents I worked with overseas were formal customs agents.
And there was always rivalry then.
There's rivalry now.
I hope that Bennett can change that, because I think it's really counterproductive.
My attitude is...
My personal attitude is that I don't care who stops it as long as it's stopped.
And I'm perfectly happy to see DEA take the credit or Border Patrol or anybody else.
Unfortunately, very few law enforcement officers feel that way.
They want the credit for themselves, and they don't want to share it.
I understand wanting credit when credit is needed.
It's possible that Bennett, once we begin to implement these strategies and plans, it may be this way.
And I hope that.
OK. Coming onto somewhat of a different subject, the VA chief, John Laws, was quoted in a time magazine as saying, we want to talk about slowing down the flow of cocaine into the United States.
we should think more in terms of demand reduction.
Now, besides the zero tolerance policy, how is Customs approaching the demand reduction, actually?
Or as Customs?
Well, we're acting on behalf of the United States government in other areas besides enforcement.
Our officers in every court, in every district probably in this country,
go out on their own time and on government time and talk to school children of all ages.
We've instituted a program where we talk to, first of all, the students to try to reinforce the general perception that they should stay away from drugs.
We do about the same as the other agencies in that respect.
We also have a program that's asking American citizens and residents of the United States to help us in the drug war by reporting anything that they think might be drug related.
If they see something suspicious, an airplane unloading in a remote airfield,
and look suspicious in a boat in some harbor or someplace, then if they think it's drugs, then they have a responsibility, we think.
And we encourage them to call us and tell us.
And we'll dispatch immediately officers and equipment to the area to try to intercept it.
Is that the B alert?
That's the B alert, yes.
There are rewards for that.
Generally, the attitude we've taken is,
I've had it for a long time, and I think we take it as a service.
We believe that we can't do it by ourselves.
We can't seal off the borders.
We can't stand hand in hand across the whole Mexican border and also across the seaports and airports and so on.
It's impossible.
The only way we're ever going to stop this is to...
stop the demand.
And that takes everybody.
Everybody has to be involved in that, not only the small part of it.
Parents have to warn their kids against drugs.
Brothers have to warn their little sisters and brothers against drugs and so on.
Everybody has to be involved.
I don't see that happening in the near future.
Going back to zero tolerance, zero tolerance, as I understand it, is the policy of arresting any person and or seizing his property that brings in any amount of illegal drugs.
Is this policy still enforced, and is it effective?
Well, it's not exactly as you describe it.
It never has been.
Zero tolerance is an attempt to make
of illegal drugs in any quantities responsible for their illegal action.
Somebody who smokes marijuana is doing it illegally.
Whether it's one ounce or half an ounce or a gram or whether it's a ton, it's illegal.
Zero tolerance simply means that if we find it,
and we will seize the conveyance in which it was transported, in most cases as an automobile or an airplane or a boat.
In recent months, if the person who owns the vehicle has no knowledge, if he can satisfy the government that
He didn't know the person who had the drugs actually had it.
He was not responsible, such as a rental agency, or if a parent lets a son or daughter take a car, or if they take it without permission, if obviously they can't control them 24 hours a day.
There are provisions that the property, that is the conveyance, is returned to the owner.
but not without penalty.
We think that by we, I mean the government.
The United States Customs Service did not invent zero tolerance.
We didn't make it up.
We only enforced it because we were told to right down from the White House.
We're an arm of the executive branch of government.
We do what we're told.
And we do it with as much energy as we can.
And when they say it's against the law to bring in any measurable amount of drugs in the United States, and if we find it, then we're going to have to bring it along.
And do you see any changes between Reagan and Bush in the disenforcement policy?
No, I don't think so.
I think Bush is just as strong against it.
As I said before, it
It's not a criminal, in most cases, a criminal proceeding.
Serial tolerance, at least the current interpretation of it, is a monetary penalty in lieu of seizing the conveyance.
We may hold up the conveyance for a while, but in most cases, they can petition and get it back.
if they can satisfy us well then we can then we will seize it and keep it there a lot there are a lot of size to this coin though because
Most people don't own their cars free and clear.
They buy them on time.
The lien holders have an opportunity to get the vehicle back.
In many cases, they do.
In most cases, they do.
Rental agencies get them back without too many problems.
In most cases, the
The cars that we've seized for either zero tolerance or for substantial amounts of drugs have been junkered.
Cars aren't worth anything anyway.
They're worth a few hundred dollars at best.
It's almost as if they know that they may get caught.
And if they do get caught, they're not going to lose a paid for valuable car.
I never thought of it that way.
We have a custom service.
We seize cars all the time out here under zero tolerance and also under substantial amounts.
And very few of the cars are actually forfeited to the government.
Very few cars that have any value on them.
Because the ones that have value are they have a lien against them, in which case the lien holder gets them back.
or borrowed or rented or in some other way not owned by the person.
The ones that seem to be owned outright are 10 years old, 150,000 miles on it, and not worth anything anymore.
According to some estimates that I've read, at least a third of all the heroin and marijuana used in the United States
is supplied through Mexico.
Do you think that this figure accurately reflects the Mexican drug threat?
And do you think that this drug threat is increasing, or has it decreased over time, or not?
I agree with the statistic, with the figure.
I think it's about right.
In fact, it may even be higher than that.
I've heard that we get about 80%
that we get in this country are either originate or are transferred through Mexico.
They don't grow cocaine in Mexico, but a lot of it comes through Mexico.
They do grow opium poppy.
We haven't seen much heroin here lately, but it's only because
Cocaine is now the most popular drug.
They grow a lot of marijuana in Mexico, as you know.
And we see more marijuana than anything, even though the United States is now growing enough marijuana in its home that it probably doesn't need to be imported.
But the new threat, from what I understand,
is something that's just as dangerous, probably more dangerous even, than crack cocaine.
And that is a crystalline substance that's derived from methamphetamines.
It's coming from East Asia.
It's coming from Korea.
We haven't seen any of that here.
yet, but if there's money in it, the Mexicans and the Latin Americans and South Americans are going to be involved in it.
Methamphetamine is what they used to call speed.
And this new form of it that's just been discovered out of Korea is finding its way into Hawaii.
It's become already a major drug problem in Hawaii.
And we're afraid it's going to find its way
in the west coast and then the rest of the country.
It gets back to this demand thing.
It doesn't seem to matter what we do.
There's always an element of the population that wants to do drugs.
They want to do crap even though they know that it's dangerous and lethal.
There are kids and
young adults who want to do it.
And the fact that we say it's bad, maybe even makes them want to do it, but I don't know why they want to do it.
As long as that demand is there, there's going to be people who want to make money, and they're going to survive.
So you think that some of these people, or the majority of these people, know that it's bad for them, but they do it anyway, or...
I think they all do.
I think they all do.
They all know it's bad, but I think the peer pressure is such that it's almost irresistible.
It's also glamorized, not so much as it used to be, but it's glamorized to some extent in movies, in music, in TV programs.
When the football player is found to have a drug habit and is suspended from football and maybe even prosecuted by the law, what happens is that he gets put in a hospital or into a cell
And he gets himself cleaned out one way or another, whether he wants to or not.
It happens.
And then he goes on TV and becomes an example of somebody who went through the drugs but was able to get off it and now
is clean and being productive.
And I think it gives the message that people, the kids and others, that, so what if I get hooked on it?
I can get off it too.
And they can put a little list of celebrities as long as your arm.
Instead, they all were in it.
They all were addicted.
And they all got off it.
And if they can do it, I can do it.
Of course, they don't all get off because a lot of them die while they're still on it.
I think it sends a bad image.

If I had my way, when Joe Hero gets busted for drugs, part of his sentence ought to be that he doesn't talk to the press, media, doesn't write a book, doesn't appear on TV, and he sure as hell doesn't do any community service to put himself in an area where he can talk to
kids who he might influence.
To me, he ought to be invisible for the next five years of his life.
I think about this a lot, and I really believe that we do more harm than good when we parade these celebrities in front of the cameras and let them tell their stories.
There's a country singer, and I can't even think of his name,
Every time I see him on TV, on an interview, he's talking about when he was in jail.
And he treats it like it was summer camp.
And he got all these people gathered around him in an interview situation.
And he's talking about the good old days when he was in prison.
And it's a stupid image.
for them to be showing.
He's laughing about it.

Here he is, a multi-millionaire country and western singer, and the message that he's giving is that he was a criminal, and he went to prison, he reformed, but what they don't say is that he's one of the few people who has this talent that he could cash in on, just like the football player.
How many people can play professional sports?

going back to the border control operation alliance was a 226 million dollar operation to fortify our borders with high-tech equipment and manpower and either of your reports received this day and if they did was it effective we haven't received any
in customs as far as I know.
We're still short-handed here by at least 20 offices.
We haven't received any assistance since this thing was publicized.
None.
I can't get desks, chairs to sit on.
I can't get equipment.
Because every time I ask for equipment, my district director says we don't have any equipment money.
Every time we try to get personnel, we're in some kind of a freeze, a hiring freeze.
Or we're told that we've recruited people.
They're in the pipeline.
But unfortunately, it takes sometimes 18 months or two years in the time to recruit somebody until he actually puts on a uniform
No, I haven't seen anything at all that would indicate that we're getting any benefit from this.
And what about the high-tech equipment that I've read about, like the balloons with the radar dishes and the helicopters and the airplanes?
Well, yes, there are those things.
How effective they are, I don't know.
We have just about every
border port on the Mexican border, and most of them have a little international airport.
We have one here in McAllen.
We have people who are working with our officer enforcement investigators.
We have uniformed officers as well who are working, trying to identify smuggling planes.
I don't know of any incident when we had called the air wing US Customs and had them scramble and go after somebody.
I don't know what they do.
I know we've got planes, and I know we've got pilots.
But I really have never seen any evidence of them down here.
We read about them from time to time.
Usually when we do read about them, it's because one of them crashed.
But as far as the other technology, yes, I think these aerostat balloons, one is up along the Rio Grande near the Big Bend area.
Another one is in the process of being great.
In fact, it's already been inflated, I think, at Rio Grande City.
The one at Rio Grande City, when it's operational,
should be able to look all the way to about 150 miles in any direction, both on the ground and in the air.
And so that would cover the whole border probably from Zapata east all the way to Brownsville in the Gulf.
How effective is that?
I don't know.
I hope it really does a job.
I have a question here about air smuggling.
You talked about the air and what it is is in many of my sources air smuggling was mentioned as a primary role of trafficking.
How is Customs tackling that problem and how could the effort be improved?
Well, we don't see air smugglers
per se at our international airport because anybody smuggling in an airplane is probably not going to come into an airport and report to customs if they're arriving from Mexico.
It's possible some of the planes that do come in have small amounts hidden on the airplane, but we have run a lot of operations on private aircraft, so we've literally
We've had mechanics literally take planes apart to look in to see if there were any drugs.
And we haven't found any drugs at all during those operations.
That doesn't mean that they're not coming in because we found a couple of things.
Number one, the pilots tend to stick together.

people in the private aircraft business, whether they're mechanics or they run these little air terminals or gas, gasoline operations, refueling operations or small terminals at these airports, they all know each other.
And I have a feeling that within a few hours of the time we hire
an aircraft mechanic would look in airframes on a regular basis.
Everybody knew about it who flew an airplane.
Everybody.
And certainly the smugglers would know as well as the non-smugglers.
That's not to say the most part.
The smugglers only say what the word gets out very quickly.
On the other hand, the border, once you get
west of Hidalgo, in the Star County and up toward Laredo, and then northwest of Laredo along the border.
It's quite remote, more so than a map of Texas would indicate.
Look at a map, it looks like there's little towns off here, but there really aren't.
There are a lot of wide open spaces.
And every ranch, and we're talking about some big ranches,
have private airstrips.
There are uncharted airstrips we call clandestine probably on both sides of the border because smuggling not only comes north but also goes south.
People smuggle drugs northward, then they smuggle consumer products
electronics, radios, TVs, things that are very expensive and high rate of duty from the United States and New Mexico.
So it's two ways.
Maybe these aerostat balloons will stop the kind of trafficking that we all know happens.
These airplanes come in.
They fly low.
under the present radar out of a air control area so that unless there's radar looking, we don't even know they're coming in.
They're required by law to report when they enter the United States airspace, but if they're carrying contraband, of course you're not going to do it.
I really think that these aerostat balloons will make a big difference because
They will see planes.
The trouble, of course, is that you can't tell if a plane is going to cross the border until it actually does so.
They can appear to be on radar, appear to be following the border, staying on the Mexican side, and then all of a sudden turn northward.
And by the time
that our radar operators pick it up and say, hey, a plane just came across.
It's too late to go after him because he's already probably going to land in one of these out-of-the-way airports, and we're not going to be able to find him anywhere.
I hope that's wrong, but that's sort of the way I feel.
It's hard.
That's our biggest threat, I think, probably with just almost impossible control.
So other than the Airstat balloon, what other technological advances would you like to see here in McAllen?
I wish we could find some electronic means of looking into cargo so we didn't have to unload trucks to find the contraband.
The only way you can look into a cargo truck to see if there are drugs hidden either among the cargo or in the conveyance itself, that is in false walls of the truck, is on the ocean.
And it takes two or three hours.
There's damage done to the product.
And we have to do this.
gadget that could, a fluoroscope or x-ray, that could look into it and that you could tell whether there was anything going on there, that would probably be a real help to us.
But I think the technology is probably available for that sort of thing, but it's so expensive it's only people can afford it, people like the Saudi Arabians.
They have those sorts of things on a test basis.
I understand there's a big machine made in France that Saudi Arabia had bought to take a look at cargo coming into their country.
But as far as I know, it hasn't been effective enough to be cost effective as far as I know.
I think they'd pay almost anything to do the work.
But they're not reliable.
But I remember for years Custom Service has tried to find things that would save them time in looking for dope.
We've had electronic sniffing machines at airports.
We've done major tests in the United States at airports.
Ones that would sniff
suitcases that came through it from there, across it from there.
We had one machine, yes, that would show an alarm that there were drugs in it.
We had another machine that we tested that would, it was hidden inside a tabletop or counter like in an airport.
passenger arrives from overseas and picks up his bags.
And the first person he talks to is an immigration officer.
He sort of bellies up to this counter on the other side of which is an immigration officer and hands him his passport.
There was a machine that supposedly would sniff this person as he got close and could tell whether he had been handling or had any on him
These gadgets were so unreliable that I reckon they gave up on all of them because I haven't heard anything about them in a long time.
I'm beginning to think maybe there is no way to really look except just tearing things apart and looking with the naked eye.
Detected dogs do that.
That's probably our best
Yeah, but I don't think they worked out because they don't have them now.
I remember when they were catching them 10 years ago.
inspector training or any training would you improve in order to make the Customs Service more efficient in combating drugs on Mexican plants?
What aspects of inspector training would you improve in order to make the Customs Service more efficient at combating drugs on Mexican plants?
Well, I think the most important
thing we can teach new inspectors would be, I don't even know if it's something we can teach.
It's a matter of attitude.
We need inspectors who have a commitment to law enforcement and a dedication to public service.
And I don't think you can teach that to people.
There are other kinds of people you go after.
but people take jobs for all kinds of reasons.
Those reasons being probably important, but they're not important to a lot of people.
A lot of people take the job because they pay well, they're steady, in an area where minimum wage is really the real problem.
You have people who...
After a few years, we made very good money as customs officers.
There was a certain amount of stature involved.
They recognized members of the community.
But if I could teach them anything, I would want to teach them just dedication, integrity, integrity, integrity.
And I just don't know if you can keep your mind.
We hope we get those people and we reinforce it, those who haven't, I think.
Because there are a lot of temptations out here.
They claim there are temptations.
I've been in the service 25 years and no one's ever offered me that.
And yet...
If it happens, I know it happens, because this happened right here in this apartment.
I was thinking about integrity.
I do have a question here about it.
I'm sorry.
Oh, no, it's fine.
So you do see that the integrity is a real, the perceived problem is a real problem.
How much of this do you see, and has it increased, the rate of which?
And what do you think is the main cause of the integrity problem?
Well, I see integrity as a problem.
I don't know what you mean by a real problem.
I think the percentage of officers who
who do things illegal out here is very, very small.
I really do.
I think it's a problem.
But in the whole scheme of custom, it's a minor problem.
We've had a couple of people arrested here, inspectors.
The reason I'm saying this is I'm trying to answer the question about
what causes it, and I don't know what causes it.
Since I've been here in Hidalgo, and this is a big port, I have to go on record as saying this is a major port of entry, even though nobody ever heard of Hidalgo, who's not from this area.
The port of Hidalgo is one of the biggest ports on the Mexican border.
There are maybe two or three in the whole border that are bigger.
We have about 100 employees here, customs, of whom, well not 100, we have about 90, of whom 75 are inspectors, and we're about 20 short from what we are right now.
Immigration service has another 50.
The agriculture has another 25.
We bring in $50 million a year in revenue.
We have a payroll of, I don't know what our payroll is, but our officers, our 80 officers, between them, earned over a million and a half dollars just in overtime last year.
And the overtime is about $20.
less than 10% of their total earnings.
So it's a major operation.
Getting back to what I started to say, since I've been here, we've lost about seven or eight officers for what I would call breaches of integrity.
Integrity lapses, or however you want to say it.
Of those,
Only three were actually indicted for criminal activity.
Every one of those three was targeted by Internal Affairs because somebody called them and said, I think this guy is doing drugs or is dishonest or is doing something illegal.
They don't target them unless somebody calls and tells them that they're suspicious.
And they respond.
In every one of these cases, two of the three cases, they gave these people who they had been told are dirty, as we say, they gave them the opportunity
They said, well, we'll find out if they are guilty.
And they gave them opportunities to break the law.
And they did.
Two of them did.
Two of them actually took bribes.
One of whom has been convicted.
I shouldn't say they actually took them.
I should say they allegedly took them.
One of whom has been convicted of two counts of bribery.
The other is about to go to trial on the same charges plus others, plus other charges.
All the charges stem from the investigation conducted by the Attorney of Affairs then providing the opportunity for these guys to break the law and they broke the law.
Perfectly legal.
I'm not saying this in any derogatory sense.
I'm in favor of this kind of law enforcement because we find out who the dishonest people are.
The third of these three was acquitted.
on drugs, on bribery, it was on passing an illegal alien.
Now, he was acquitted of that in court, and he's trying to get his job back.
I don't know whether he will or not, but I have no opinion on whether he should be coming back or not.
The other five of that group of eight resigned in every case
under some kind of suspicion, in most cases because they were consorting with known criminals, even though there was no specific charges against them.
One person resigned because he was offered a bribe, didn't take the bribe, but didn't report
to internal affairs that he was a prophet of God.
And so they confronted him with that and then he decided to resign and then go through trial and so on.
But all of these, if in trying to sort out what these people all had in common, it's difficult without
making almost making an ethnic slur because all of them are locals.
All of them are Mexican Americans.
All of them have contacts on both sides of the border.
All of them grew up in this area.
And all of them, as I say, have friends, relatives, some of whom have contacts with
It's not to say that every local person is a potential criminal.
It's not to say at all, but that seems to be the problem.
